Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Surface wave and body wave modeling of attenuation in the mantle transition zone
Award.AbstractNarration:
Seismic images of the Earth?s interior play a central role in the geophysical and geochemical modeling of the planet?s structure and dynamics. The majority of these seismic models contain three-dimensional variations in wave speed. Attenuation, or Q−1, tomography has so far progressed more slowly than velocity tomography because wave amplitudes and spectral content, which are the primary data in attenuation studies, require a more complex interpretation than traveltimes and phase delays. In addition to intrinsic wave attenuation, amplitudes are affected by focusing due to spatial gradients in wave speed, the presence of scatterers, and the earthquake rupture process.Progress in the research of, for example, the nature of the low-velocity zone in the upper mantle, the role of hydrous phases in the mantle, and material flow through the transition zone depends critically on the availablity of models of seismic velocity and attenuation. Because wave speed is
influenced by several factors (temperature, composition, melt), robust and unique interpretations of tomographic velocity images require accompanying images of the attenuation structure in the mantle, ideally with comparable spatial resolution.

The main thrust of the proposed work involves the development of a new 3-D global-scale model for wave attenuation in the upper mantle that builds upon our previous modeling. The model will be constrained by new fundamental-mode and higher-mode surface-wave amplitudes. Notably, the overtone data set has not been used in attenuation studies before and will allow resolution of the transition zone. An important component of this research is the investigation into improved theoretical and practical treatments for focusing effects on wave amplitude, including a simultaneous inversion for global shear-velocity and attenuation models. A critical component of ?resolution testing? involves model interrogation with independent data sets of body-wave amplitudes and spectra, and with realistic 3-D synthetics. They will investigate to what extent P and SH spectra, S and SS amplitudes, and regional waveform data can be reconciled with our new attenuation model. They will also examine a number of critical theoretical approximations using SPECFEM synthetics

POR.DRECONTENT:
Seismic waves generated by earthquakes travel through the rocks in Earth’s crust and mantle. Sensitive instruments called seismometers, placed on the surface of the Earth, can record these waves and allow seismologists to determine how fast the waves traveled and how much energy the waves lost traveling between the earthquake to the seismometer. With measurements of wave speed and energy loss, scientists can estimate the temperature of the rocks in Earth’s deep interior. These measurements can also tell us about the chemical composition of the rocks, whether the rocks are partially molten, and if there are reservoirs of petroleum, water, or carbon dioxide deep inside the Earth. Since the properties and motions of rocks in the crust and mantle control many important processes at Earth’s surface and affect the people who live there—including earthquakes, volcanoes, and mountain building—there is a fundamental need to understand what is going on deep inside the Earth. This same information also helps us understand the history of distant planets like Venus and Mars.

 

The main focus of this project was to develop a better understanding of how the energy content of seismic waves changes as the waves travel. Most studies of seismic waves only consider the speed of seismic waves, but energy loss is equally useful. We examined how factors other than energy loss can manifest as energy loss and introduce bias into estimates of temperature below Earth’s surface. We also performed a separate study, focused just on the continental land masses, to try to understand why the interior cores of continents, known as cratons, have been able to avoid destruction and remain intact at the surface. The answer to this question bears directly on how continents were assembled billions of years ago and whether new cratons are able to be formed today.
